text: 16oz can, pours a dark brown color with a slight light brown head. The aroma has hints of tart fruits, hops, and malts. Has an interesting blend of sweet and bitter notes. Smooth, slightly robust, and you get hints that this is a boozy brew. Rather interesting flavors for a black ale.
Old rating from CBC 2014. Beer in the glass deep black, small head. Malty-fruity aroma. Starts heavy malty, stouty, earthy-notes. More and more hoppy-dry, bitter background. Interesting!

Can, 1 pint. Opaque dark brown with a frothy brown head. Roasted and hoppy aromas, hints of spices. Medium to robust bodied, moderate carbonation. Texture is oily. Medium sweet, medium bitter. Rich roasted and hoppy flavors into a smooth malty bitter finish.

Can, 1 pint. A dark beer with a big foamy brown head. Aromas of floral hops, pine, roasted malts and alcohol. Taste is bitter with low sweetness. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Rich roasted coffee character and a hoppy finish. Some mint at the end.

Minnesota Trip Beer #24. Keg at Surly, 5/8/16. Clear dark brown, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of chocolate, resin, grapefruit, herbal hops. The taste is chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, grapefruit. Medium bodied, low carbonation, mild lingering bitterness.

Can: April 24th 2016: Aroma is heavy from spruce, raw licorice, orange peels and piney hops. Taste is massive, with strong roasted notes, raw grapefruit rind, pine oil. The bitterness that kicks in is truly impressive, really harsh and strong. This is one of the best Black IPAs Ive ever had, but take my warning, I do really like exaggerated brews so if youre into a more settled and soft approach while you listen to Nickelback, choose something else.

Can with massive thanks to Scott. Pours a very thick looking motor oil black with a cream colored head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee and spruce with maybe a hint of lemon and mint. Flavor is very solid... lots of that chocolate malt presence, a brash pine presence and a citrusy/minty finish. (Im not completely sold on mint, but that seems to be what Im getting here. I cant think of any other beers that werent advertised as "mint" beers that I have got that flavor on, though...) Damned good stuff, but that kind of goes to figure, right?

Dark, minimal head, perfectly balanced toasty malt and hop. One of the better black IPAs I've had.

"Blackened is the end" - Metallica. Surly, what is this unholy concoction thou hast wrought? It pours black with a rich head that stays till the bitter end. And the end IS bitter, just as it is in the beginning. It starts with roasted malt bitterness. Tobacco, coffee, smoky wood, bitter chocolate. Then it changes into hop briskness. Zesty, leafy, woodsy (again, but different) and resinous. 999 is the new heretical number. Should you choose to drink of this wicked brew, you can abandon any hopes of peacefully shuffling off this mortal coil. Instead, itll be burned away, and you too will be blackened.
On tap at El Bait Shop. Black appearance with a tan head. Dark, roasty malts balanced by a moderate hop bitterness with notes of chocolate, pine and light citrus fruits. Good.

16oz can. Medium brown head atop cola dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, pine/grapefruit, some roast. Taste is moderately sweet, pine/grapefruit, some roast, light coffee. Medium-full body, some stickiness, light effervescence.

Draft @ Mikkeller CBC 2014.
Dak brown, brown head. Of-dry, medium body, mid to high bitterness, balanced CO2.
Hoppy, roasted, resin, spruce, orange peel, coffee, ashes. (2014-05 backlog)

Taste starts with a short milky sweetness, then transforms into great pine and dark chocolate bitterness. The finishing is long and toasty and the mouthfeel is oily.

16 oz can to pint. Dark brown pour with 3 finger beige head. Very roasty smell vs the citrus smell others report. It has good body and nice flavor. Bitter flavor but the malt aromas overpower the hop aromas. ABV pretty well hidden. More of a dark ale than black IPA. I would like to have more of the citrus or pine flavors of black IPAs. This is good beer but didnt knock my socks off like I expected.

A 1 pint can canned on 26th January 2016 and poured into an oversized wine glass. It poured a dark dark brown colour with an orange hue and a slightly less than one finger tanned head that dissipated fairly quickly but left nice lacing. Aromas are a mix of piney and citrus orange hops and roasty dark chocolate. Taste starts sweet-ish citrusy orange followed by caramel malt, light roast coffee and chocolate plus a hint of char before ending with a lasting pine and juicy citrus light bitterness. Medium bodied with moderate to low carbonation. Overall a nicely balanced Black IPA that hides its high ABV well.

COD 1/26/16. Pours black, as advertised. World class head volume, lacing and retention.

Outstanding, and surprisingly fruity, nose of pine, dank, citrus (lime) and tropical (passion fruit) hops. Underneath is a mild sweetness that I cant identify when cold, but seems to be caramel as it warms.

Light medium body that has a rather slick texture. Superb carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and a prickly finish.

The quite outstanding flavor profile is unique. It begins with a blend that quickly devolves into lime, dank and pine. The middle provides a succulent caramel based sweetness that arrives in wave fashion. Underneath is a layer from the dark malts that hints at bakers chocolate and a touch of char, but not roast per se. Fairly mild bitterness arrives mid-palate and is a combination of pine, dank and zest. As the bitterness fades, the sweetness arrives coupled with a note of passion fruit. The finish is a slow sweet fade that takes on a zest quality as it lingers with dank and pine playing around the edges.

Dark brown color with a tall, lasting light tan head. Aromas of citric to light resin hops, backed by a toasted to light roasted malt element. Sweet roasted malt start, but not a strong roast. Mild feel and rather soft. Is it lingers, you get some pine, wood, citrus, cocoa and light fruit. Most of the BIPAs have not been in my wheelhouse, this one is no exception. I enjoy this one, but its just a sipping hoppy dark ale. 4/14

Tap at the source. Pours black, tan head. Aroma is citrus, orange, roasted malt, actually some really nice citrus, almost tropical fruit notes. Flavor is roasted malt, and citrus. Chocolate. Wow, probably one of the best black IPAs Ive had in a while.

Can, thanks PotjeBier! Deep dark brown color. Creamy head. Caramel, red berries and soft herbal hops in the aroma. Malty sweetish, soft caramelly, Firm Hoppy flavor with red berries and roast. Grassy notes. Very Nice.

Keg @ Mimosa, MSP. Deep brown pour with a luxurious creamy tan head. Aroma is pretty hoppy. Plenty of pine wood character. PNW C-hops. Pine cone forest. A bit of cheese and orange peel too. Flavor is fairly bold and rich, which youd expect for a beer of this profile. Chewy charred malt character. Burnt pine. Caramel cheesecake. Leafy strong bitter finish. Full body, supple carb. Nice stuff.

Pours a black color with ruby highlights when held up to a light. Large creamy tan head that doesnt disappear. Lots of sticky lacing. Slight alcohol aroma with malt and sugar. Mouth feel is dense like you want to chew it. A sugary, fruity flavor that turns to grapefruit. Lingering pithy bitterness. You can sense the alcohol.

Opaquish dark brown with red notes, light tan head. Nose comes off as raw pumpkin, some light pine resin. Some honey. Fairly bitter, some sweetness. Chewy, heavier body, a bit of acid. Decent.

Dark malt and hops introduce a shifty interplay of pineapple acid, blackberry, prune, gooseberry; slithery and mystifying, fun. The flavor reveals the giveaway tangerine zest and chocolate partnership that defines and often pigeonholes the style. Balanced though big and mildly hot, persistently drab in flavor, few nuances to find. Muted carbonation. Sweeter, tropical fruit leaning mid palate; syrupy texture taking over in the end.
Black. Mediocre next to other options here. Pretty hoppy. Is this a black ipa? Tasted at stlhops 8th anniversary party

Can at the March DC Tasting. Poured a black color with a small brown head. Aroma was roasted malts, chocolate, roasted malts. Roasted malts, pine resin. Pretty tasty.

Once again, Ratebeer lost my rating.... WTF? Anyway, this was an amazing beer! One of the best imperial black IPAs Ive ever had. Not sure if they still make it or it was a one off, but grab it if you can. It was pretty expensive at nearly $20 for a four pack of tallboys, but worth every penny!

Pours a clear black body under a frothy and creamy beige head that had nice retention. The aroma is really nice, lots of citrusy hops over a chocolaty and roasted malt base. The flavor is very bitter and citrusy up front. Finishes more malty with great lingering dark cocoa and roasted malt notes. This is really good stuff, and I dont think that its even all that fresh. Medium bodied with fizzy carbonation and a mouth coating finish. Really good stuff.

Yields a motor oil black color, with a big, light brown, fluffy head.

Produces an intense, aromaful nose, consisting of big exotic fruit chunks, blending into roasty, warm earth. While the malts stay pleasantly focused on their mellow grain toast quality, the hops produce a great aroma diversity, featuring sappy lime, as well as juicy blood orange, creating an inviting complexity, while also adding a subtle sweetness to the malts. Never experienced a black ipa with such a profound resin quality, lending a rich ripeness to the fruity hops.

Has a creamy, rich mouthfeel to it, packing a pungent hop punch during the finish, amazingly well coated up by hops and malts, while resulting in a pleasant warmth. Very versatile on the palate, no notes of alcohol whatsoever, while the balance is able to handle all extremes going on in this.

This has such a clean, calm beginning, consisting of grain defined bread, bakers chocolate and a very soft aqueous quality, slowly turning into a creamy direction. After establishing this very smooth taste foundation, sour lime announces an uncompromising hop armada, while adding a bitter juice note as its harbinger, perfectly adding to the beers already established flavors. The following hop maelstrom overpowers them almost, if it werent for the throughout detectable creaminess in this, adding a subtle but effective balancing quality to the malts. Luscious orange, together with wet grass and prickly kiwi and a whiff of papaya exhibit the diversified hop profile, which displays an intense dryness, together with a malt compatible fruitiness, finally joined by a distinct roasty malt aspect. Flavors turn more and more intense, while reaching their peak after the swallow, soothed by the noteable roasted malts and creamy nouthfeel, still allowing the hops to produce a long lasting, lime aftertaste.

What an extreme beer, which is true for its taste and for its well working balance. Flavors dont ever seem to stop evolving on the palate, while never revealing any signs of its higher alcohol content at all, instead the beer is defined by an utmost smooth mouthfeel.

16 oz can, shared @ Borresteijns. Dark color, but not quite black/opaque. Beige head. Aromas of resin, drop/licorice, bay leaves, zwart-wit. Retronasal its moderate sweet, drop. Flavor is moderate sweet, roast, drop, moderate bitter. Medium bodied. Long finish with resin, moderate bitter, roast, coffee.

Blakkr has a very thick, beige, creamy head, a very dark brown (NOT blakkr than blakk, though) appearance, and heavy lacing left behind. The aroma is of bright, citrus, indistinguishable fruit, with maybe a background bread. Taste is of black bread, some not-so-strong bitterness, and sweet, fruity, hops (yes, I said "sweet"). Mouthfeel is medium, and Blakkr finishes semi-dry and easy drinking (for a 10% beer, which presents no alcohol). RJT

.5L can, thanks Potje! Black colour, beige head. Aroma of grapefruit, pine, brown malts, coffee, caramel. Flavour is sweet, malty, grapefruit, caramel, coffee, hint of laurel, mint, pumpernickel, bitter hoppy finish. Medium bodied. Good.

Thanks cards04! Very dark with a thin tan foam. Aroma is pine, wood, ash, and coffee. Chocolate, hop bitterness, and burnt wood top this full bodied black ale. Finish is anise and tobacco. Plenty complex but not as good as the 3 Floyds version.

16 oz. can from arminjewell- thanks again, Armin! Lives up to its name on the pour. Black as night, with a small off-white head that leaves a ring, streaky lace, and small wisps of film. Roasted and toasted malts, tobacco, earth, burnt sugar, dark chocolate, and a little citrus peel. At first I detected a kind of soy/umami note that went away after breathing for a minute. The whole thing mellows over time. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a roasty, bitter mouthfeel. Good black IPA.

16 Oz can. Pours black with beige head. Strong piney citrus aroma. Taste follows with a bitter malt dry finish. Pretty good stuff.

Pours black with creamy head. Good retention. Aroma is heavy pine, hops, and creamy malt. Taste is malt, Citra hops and spicy pine. Nice mixture. Love the idea of brewers getting together and getting creative. Very good.

(can) Price dropped by 2 bucks on this, so decided to give it a try. Pours black with a large tan head that retains well. Why not 5. Aroma is pretty potent with plenty of pine, grapefruit, pineapple, and cookies. Some roasted malt is also present. Flavor holds an unexpected amount of decadent chocolate (like a lightly bitter dark) that yields a bit of a brownie character. This is coupled with some orange zest and more pine with a bit of saltiness thrown in towards the later stages of the finish. The alcohol is pretty well masked here. Mouthfeel is quite thick and carb is decent. Overall this is decent, but even after a $2 reduction, I dont think this is worth the high asking price.

50cl can, recieved as a extra in a trade. poured a very dark brown colour with a tanned head on top. nose of thick roasted malts, sweet chocolate notes, slight tropical fruit notes, pine hop bitterness, melons, ash notes, resins, big hop bitterness. mocha, soy sauce, cookie dough, alcohol is well hidden. very enjoyable and 2 flavors that are very well blended together! nice refreshing afertaste!
Big roasty and drying finish. Thanks for sharing JOhn. God amount of orange hops. I would like more, good still.

Pours black with a large light tan head. Aromas of cocoa, some floral hops. Taste is bitter and lightly sweet. Flavors of light coffee, some roast, bitter flowers, cocoa. Finished semi sweet, kind of chalky and very milkshake like. Above average but not mind blowing.
Aroma is pine, citrus and fruit. The flavor is chocolate, dark malts, grapefruit, fruit and a mix of tart//sour and heat in the finish.

16oz can. Pours black with a foamy tan head. Aroma is of hops, pine, tropical fruit, and toasted malt. Taste starts off with a piney and juicy tropical hop flavor. The hop character is balanced out by a toasty malt backbone. Lingering resiny hop character. Finish is dry, toasted malt. Surprisingly well balanced. As it warms up, more tropical fruit starts to come through. Mouthfeel is very bitter, and burns the throat a little bit. Decent.

Black pour with a one finger, tan head. Aroma is full of floral and tropical fruit hops, citrus and sharp pine to a lesser extent, some dark berry and ashy roast, and a little husky, spicy grain. Flavor is light roast, dark toasted bread, oatmeal, oily pine, dank marijuana, guava and mango heavy tropical fruit, bitter, juicy and oily citrus, spicy hops, a little grass and black tea. Medium body, creamy to syrupy entry, dry, slightly syrupy middle, medium carbonation and dry, slightly astringent finish. Really tasty stuff, could use a bit more malt character to sell the Black Ale/Black IPA thing.

Sweet cocoa, marshmallows, graham crackers, grassy hops, earthy, toasted malt, and grapefruit in the aroma. Taste is cocoa nibs, coffee, grapefruity hops, candied oranges, caramel, roasty, marshmallows, and brown sugar with a big bitter finish. Full mouthfeel with high carbonation. Tasty stuff.

The licorice aspect is much more pronounced, as is the roasted grain, bridging into porter territory just a little.  That licorice is crazy.  I dont remember tasting that so strongly in a beer before.  A much more interesting beer now.

My Bottom Line:
Halfway between chocolate cake and fruit cake, this Imperial Black IPA sculpts tantalizing flavors spanning from licorice to coffee, all brushed by coniferous hops resins.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam covers the gleaming darkness.
-The mouthfeel is succulently rich.
-The flavor profile is different and memorable.
-There is balance within the intensity.
-Alcohol is well hidden by the hop bitterness and rich malt sugars.

Draft at ChurchKey. Pours a dark, slightly reddish chestnut color. Aroma is pine, light roast, coffee, lemon zest, stone fruit. Very drinkable beer: taste is coffee, cocoa, pine, grapefruit juice, and mouth-drying bitterness (but not too much). Very good.

Fresh 16oz can poured into an over-sized Barolo tulip.Man the aroma tells you from the git that youre going on a ride. The smell is very rich and complex. The earthy and floral hop notes jump to the fore. Seriously brash barnyard and coffee aromas follow. I picked up just a bit of chocolate, overall it reminded very much of a floral coffee like a peaberry or Guatemala but with dank hop characteristics.The appearance is where this black ale shines. . a deep dark cola color with a creamy but thin head. If anything Blakkr appears a bit under carbonated. As for the taste, there is so much going on. This is definitely a sipper-slash end of evening-slash"dessert beer. It has the weight and mouthfeel of a substantial porter or stout with the earthy hop kick. By turns there is the dual bitterness of the hops and espresso like malts,then a strong molasses like sweetness and a delightful liquorice bite in the back end. The alcohol is well hidden in the taste but you will feel it by the end of the can. Absolutely no burn. The palate is very solid, It is sweet and bitter, round and dry by turns with a nice pop of citrus. For sweet stout lovers it will be familiar, for West Coast black IPA fans it maybe hoppy enough but a bit big on the sweet malts especially as it warms. Overall, this is a very tasty and complex offering though a little spendy at about $4.50 a sixteen oz. can. Savor a Blakkr reflectively or pair with a rich stew, tangy rib or decadent chocolate dessert. A very good, occasion black ale. UMPH..home town love!

Poured from 16oz can, pours black with a thin tan head and spotty lacing, aroma has quite a bit of citrus with a kick of roast as well, pretty dank, the flavor has a citrus front end with some chocolate and ash in the finish, light mouthfeel, pretty good stuff.
On draft at Churchkey in DC. Pours black with a tan head. Citrus nose. Flavors of pine resin, caramel and a hint of butterscotch, all with smoky overtones. Complex and tasty.

Khaki colored head and a black color that barely turns crimson red when held to a light; Good lacing. Aroma of mangoes, citrus hops, orange peel, mild chocolate malts and lemons. Flavor of citrus & piney hops, mangos, roasted barley, chocolate malts and a chocolate-orange/resin aftertaste. Heavy body but light carbonation. Very tasty and a must have!
Interesting concept. I love black IPAs this one was a little too chocolate forward for me. Loved the aromatics though.

Draft at Butcher and the Boar. Pours a jet black color with a big tan head and some lacing. Aroma is hoppy, tropical fruit, mango, pineapple, grapefruit. Medium on the palate with creamy carbonation. Flavor is a sweet, malty, roasty, bitter, coffee, hoppy, grapefruit, with a bittersweet chocolate finish. Excellent.

This monster pours an almost black color with an off white head. Big hop flavors and aromas that are kept in check by some nice chocolate and caramel. I would enjoy this one fresh to get all the nice hop goodness.

Can @ Brewbies 2014. Black pour with a khaki head. Smells of roasted malt, coffee, and herbal hops. Sweet dark fruit, some cocoa powder, pine, and a bit of citrus rind. Flavor is intensely bitter and a touch chalky. Herbal, woody, and piney hop character with very light citrus (mostly bitter pith and rind). Cocoa powder, lots of roasted malt, and coffee. Kind of astringent to me. Not a big fan.

>> Near black pour, cloudy, deep mocha layer of foam. Nose is doggy (volatile), big savory roasted pineapple and mango. Perfect black IPA nose. Taste is big grilled pineapple mango. Rich, dank, spicy tamarind, sage, lemon pepper. Solid, on point Black IPA.

Can, pours a pitch black body with a thin, light brown head that quickly dissipates. Strong hop aroma, mainly citrus, apricot, and grapefruit with some pine. Taste is similar with some roasted/burnt malt flavor that nicely complements the hops. Strong hop flavor throughout the palate. Bitter grapefruit finish.
Creamy black ale definitely sums up surly and 3 FloydsI one great bear. Not much head, tangy and delicious.

Cask pour at Night of the Living Ales 2014 (Chicago, IL). Pours a dark blackish brown hue, well hazed and near opaque with some gentle brownish glow on the bottom and edges. A thicker bubbly light brown head atop stays as a frothy layer, laces ok. Aromas are tropical fruit, sweeter hop fruity complexity with some citrus, bready malts, florals, and gentle pine. A touch sweet. Initial is decently bitter, a touch thicker with some gentle black malt, fruity hops meet pine and floral bitterness. Touches of grapefruit rind, citrus and pine touch. Some gentle girthy body on a bit more display due to the cask carbonation levels. Backend is a bit of tropical fruit, gentle toastiness and bready malt. The fruit dominates more than the FFF version, the cask carbonation makes it a bit thicker. The fruity hop element seems to dominate here, which would be awesome, but a lack of carbonation and lacking overall complimenting bitterness seems the downgall here. A bit of a one trick pony and a bit sweet/fruity without really showing much "Black IPA" character. This deserves a re-rate via can pour, gotta stand as it is for now though.
16oz can at home, poured in Imperial pint glass. Great roasty-toasty aroma wafting from tan head. Balanced amount of hops, even from a Surly IPA. This beer went down easily and quickly!

16 oz can. Deep brown nearing black with a big tan head. Strong resinous, piney apricot hops with a sugary malt background and tea. Quite sweet with a piney bitter finish. Body is heavier with a cough syrup consistency. Awesome can art and nice to have a black ipa without the burnt sugar or black licorice aromas dominant. Also cool to see a special brew in regular packaging instead of a bomber.
Nice black pour with a tan head, aroma is big citrus notes like Abrasive. Taste is bold citrus and fades into some chocolate maltiness, nice.

Poured from a 16oz can. Aroma is pine and roasty malt. Flavors are pine, citrus, roast, coffee, caramel, and chocolate. Awesome beer! Actually quite balanced for what it is. Another great beer from surly!

February 27, 2014 - on tap at the brewery. Black pour with some head. Citrus hops and roasted malt in aroma. Taste was consistent with aroma, but also had some chocolate. Medium to full body, relatively smooth and just a slight bitter finish.

Tap at Surly. Pours black with substantial brown head, fluffy head. Aroma is citrus hops, some roasted malts. Taste is that of an IPA, I get very little of the roasted malts, chocolate, etc. that usually accompany a black IPA. It is black only in appearance really. Tastes somewhat close to Abrasive, really a pretty good beer and cool artwork.
Can at home. Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of pine, roast, malt and citrus. Very solid brew.

Color me shocked. I typically hate this style, but this IPA wasnt all that black besides the color. Nice full hoppy aroma, similar to abrasive. Flavor is pretty sweet up front with tons hops in the finish. Almost no roast, great beer.

16 oz. can. Labeled as "III Floyds. Surly. Real Ale. Blakkr Imperial Black Ale." This is the Surly-brewed and canned version. Excellent hops dominate the aroma. Fresh, herbal, woody, earthy, mouthwatering smell features pine, peach, raspberry, cherry, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, salt, and peat scents. Roasted malts do make their presence felt in the aroma. Pours an opaque, dark brown with a pronounced amber hue. Small amount of short-lasting taupe head. Produces little and short-lasting lacing. The beer is not nearly as dark in color as the name implies. Honestly, the average stout is at least as blakk or even blakkr (sorry; I couldnt help myself). That said, I actually like the appearance better as an amber-tinted dark brown than as a black beer. Dryness initially dominates the flavor, but a tasty maltiness develops upon multiple sips. Boozy. Citrus (lemon and grapefruit) and milk chocolate. There is a pronounced earthiness, evoking the rich, dark soil of fertile farmland. Light, piney, dry aftertaste. Medium to heavy body. Soft in the palate; its very typically a Surly beer in its oaty softness. Remarkably easy to drink. Blakkr is surprisingly light, pleasant, friendly, and happy. Its not the Abrasive/Darkness cross that many have speculated. Rather, it is more a hoppy double brown, a Double Bender if you well (I apologize for my Surly-centricity, but I am a Minnesotan, after all). It is more hippy blues rock than heavy metal, the Cream of beers, despite the brewers inspiration. It may be arguably mis-marketed, but it is highly enjoyable and likable. I gave a bonus point to the overall score for all-around excellence and satisfaction.

Picked up a four-pack at Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, Minnesota. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with a rocky beige head that really sticks to the glass edge, even in a plastic cup, with all the lacing expected. Dont even think of using a plastic cup, Glass It! Aroma of citrusy and floral hops, grapefruit, a hint of Bakers chocolate, coffee and a hint of white pine. Taste is full bodied, soft carbonation with flavors of dark chocolate, cascade-ish/grapefruity hops, white pine and toasted dark malts. Finish is quite thick for a BIPA with a well balanced chocolate/sweet dark malt and grapefruit aftertaste with a sweet citrus and red grapefruit aftertaste. Unlike anything else Ive tried from Surly. Malty, sweet citrusy hoppy, alcohol warmth, and oily finish. Couldnt ask for a more suitable and full-bodied beer to be released during this year of the Multi-Polar Vortexes.

Tap. Dark black pour, ample 1/2 head of lasting carbonation and an aroma of mellow dark roasty malt and nice noticeable hops. Flavor is nice dark malty base which melds nicely with mildy roastiness and enought hops to make it noticeable. Alcohol is well hidden on this, be careful!

Aroma of piney root beer and citrus. Dark reddish brown with fading tan head. Taste is bitter, resiny, with some slight alcohol. Slight maltiness which I cant explain, but very nice. Palate is fairly thin for a 10% beer, but goes great with the style.
Can @ home. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma is roasty malt, coffee, citrus, pine. Flavor is lots of pine, some citrus, mild coffee, and sweet roasty malt. Well done.

Can pour into an IPA glass. Darkness abounds, moderate to heavy foam. Aromas of malty grapefruit. Bitterness hides the higher (9.99%) abv. A bit spendy since its $3 more than Abrasive... but a great BIPA.
Can at the release party at Grumpys NE. Black pour with a monster tan head. Pine notes in the aroma. Taste is pine, some citrus sweetness, and roast. Big and bold. Very good!
